headline.main-hed: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Five Militants in Pakistan's North Waziristan

alt-summary-body.p: A U.S. drone strike in Pakistan's North Waziristan tribal region killed at least five militants of the Afghan Haqqani Network, intelligence officials said, the second such strike on the militant group this month.

headline.main-hed: U.S. drone strike kills five militants in Pakistan's North Waziristan region
U.S. Drone Strike Kills Five Militants in Pakistan's North Waziristan -- Update
U.S. Drone Strike Kills 5 in Pakistan

summary-body.p: A U.S. drone strike in Pakistan's North Waziristan tribal region killed at least five militants of the Afghan Haqqani Network, the second such strike on the militant group this month.

headline.main-hed: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Five Militants in Pakistan's North Waziristan
headline.deck: Attack Comes as Islamabad Launches Assault Against Fighters

article-body.byline: By Safdar Dawar and Qasim Nauman
article-body.p: PESHAWAR, Pakistan—A U.S. drone strike in Pakistan's North Waziristan tribal region killed at least five militants of the Afghan Haqqani Network on Wednesday, intelligence officials said, the second such strike on the militant group this month.

This was the first drone strike in the country since Pakistan launched a full-scale military operation against militants in North Waziristan earlier this week. At least 11 militants, including a senior Haqqani Network commander, were killed last week when two drone strikes broke a six-month lull in such air attacks in North Waziristan.

highlight.link: Afghan Candidate Boycotts Count of Votes

article-body.p: The Haqqani Network is an insurgent group affiliated with the Afghan Taliban but is largely autonomous. It is based in North Waziristan, and operates across the border in eastern Afghanistan. Designated a terrorist organization by the U.S. in 2012, it has carried out high-profile attacks against Western targets in Afghanistan, including one on the U.S. Embassy in Kabul in 2011.

The drone strike on Wednesday targeted a Haqqani Network compound in the Danday Darpakhel area before dawn on the outskirts of North Waziristan's capital Miranshah, Pakistani intelligence officials said. In addition to the five killed, two militants were wounded in the strike. A store and at least two vehicles were destroyed. The death toll couldn't be independently verified.

The government of Pakistan condemned the strike, as it usually does. "Pakistan regards such strikes as a violation of its sovereignty and territorial integrity," the foreign ministry said in a statement.

Pakistan's full-scale offensive against militants in North Waziristan entered its fourth day Wednesday. At least 200 militants and eight Pakistani soldiers have been killed so far in the operation, according to the military. The offensive began Sunday, a week after a brazen Taliban attack on the country's busiest airport in Karachi.
Several militant groups, including al Qaeda, the Haqqani Network and the Pakistani Taliban are based in North Waziristan.

Pakistan's government had come under intense pressure to initiate military action against militant groups, especially the Pakistani Taliban, who claimed responsibility for the Karachi attack. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif initiated a tentative peace process with the group, which is allied with al Qaeda and formally known as the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan, in January. A cease-fire was announced in March but ended in April after preliminary talks stalled.

The government allowed the first groups of civilians to leave North Waziristan on Wednesday. The region had been sealed off by the military on Sunday when the operation began, trapping civilians looking to escape the fighting. Aid agencies believe as many as 400,000 people may be displaced by the operation. The government said Tuesday that it was prepared to care for affected civilians.

Despite widespread political support for the North Waziristan operation, Mr. Sharif's ruling Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz party has come under pressure following clashes between police and supporters of charismatic anti-Taliban preacher Tahir ul Qadri in the central Pakistani city of Lahore on Tuesday. Those clashes killed at least eight people.

Mr. Qadri said Wednesday he doesn't consider the judicial inquiry commission created to investigate the killings legitimate. "How can an inquiry be impartial if it is based on evidence compiled by the murderers themselves?" Mr. Qadri, who is based in Canada, said in comments broadcast on Pakistani TV channels.
Opposition leaders, including cricket star-turned-politician Imran Khan, accused Mr. Sharif's party of using police brutality to try to silence opponents.
A senior police official in Lahore and an official in the Punjab chief minister's office declined to comment, saying it would be inappropriate to say anything with the matter under judicial review.
